chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
<speak>
    Letter One<break time="500ms"/> On the Catholic Name
<break time="1s"/>
</speak>

Pacianus to his brother Sympronian, greetings.

If it is not a carnal intention but, as I believe, a spiritual calling that prompts you to examine the faith of Catholic truth from us, then you should have indicated which different beliefs you were following. You seem to have started far from the source and origin of the principal Church, not holding to its fountain and beginning. You should have revealed what specifically caused you to break from the unity of our body. For those parts that require healing need to be exposed. Now, with the matter hidden, we do not see which parts of us most need curing.

So many heresies have arisen from the Christian head that the volume of their names is immense. For instance, to omit the heretics among the Jews, like Dositheus the Samaritan, the Sadducees, and the Pharisees: it would be too long to count how many emerged during the times of the apostles: Simon Magus, Menander, Nicolaus, and others whom obscure fame has concealed. What about later times with Ebion, Apelles, Marcion, Valentinus, and Cerdon: and not long after them, the Cataphrygians and Novatians, not to mention the more recent swarms?

So who should I first refute in writing? The paper will not hold all their names if you wish to list them. Except that in your writings, which condemn repentance everywhere, you declare yourself aligned with the Phrygians. But even among these, their error is so manifold and diverse that it is not just one thing in them that opposes repentance, but rather, like the many-headed Hydra, several aspects must be cut off.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If your intention is not carnal but a spiritual calling, Lord, and you seek to examine our faith in the Catholic truth, you should have clearly indicated which teachings you intend to follow and how they differ. You, who began far from the source and did not adhere to the origins of the main Church, should have revealed the primary cause that divided our unity. For those parts that need healing must be exposed.

Now, with the letters, so to speak, closed, we do not see which parts need our special attention. So many heresies have emerged from the Christian faith that the list of their names is immense. To set aside the heretics of the Jews: Dositheus the Samaritan, the Sadducees, and the Pharisees. It would take too long to count how many arose during the apostles' times: Simon Magus, Menander, Nicolaus, and others whom history has obscured.

What about later times with Ebion, Apelles, Marcion, Valentinus, and Cerdon? And soon after them, the Cataphrygians and Novatians, not to mention newer groups? Who then should I refute first by letter? The names of all would not fit on a single page if you wish. Except that in your writings, condemning repentance everywhere, you declare agreement with the Phrygians. But in those very writings, dear Lord, the error is so varied and diverse that it is not just one thing against repentance, but many issues like the Hydra's heads that must be addressed.

First, they rely on many authors. For I think even the Greek Blastus is among them: Theodotus and Praxeas also taught your people at some time. Those notable Phrygians, who falsely claim to be inspired by Leucius, boast that they were instructed by Proculus. Following Montanus, Maximilla, and Priscilla, they stirred up many controversies about the Paschal day, the Paraclete, the apostles, and the prophets. And many other issues, like this about the Catholic name and the forgiveness of repentance.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, if we want to discuss all these matters, we need your full attention. Even if I can't fully instruct you on these topics, we must still serve those seeking knowledge in any way possible. To inform you, we will briefly talk about the subjects you've deemed important enough to write about.

If you want to understand our beliefs more fully, you need to speak more plainly about your own. This way, by asking clearly, you won't leave us wondering whether you're questioning or provoking us.

As for the current matters, first of all, I ask you not to give authority to error. You mentioned that no one in the entire world could refute or persuade you against your beliefs.

Even if we are unskilled, the Spirit of God is most skilled. And even if we are unfaithful, God is faithful, who cannot deny Himself. Second Timothy, Chapter 2, Verse 13.

Moreover, for a long time, it was not permitted to contend with the priests of God. The Apostle says, "We have no such custom, nor does the Church of God." First Corinthians, Chapter 11, Verse 16.

After a single admonition, as you know, a contentious person should be avoided. Titus, Chapter 3, Verse 10.

But who can persuade someone against their will? Therefore, brother, it is your fault, not theirs, if no one has persuaded you of what is best. Even today, you have the power to disregard our writings if you prefer to reject them rather than accept them.

Furthermore, many resisted the Lord Himself and His apostles. The truth cannot persuade anyone unless they agree with it through their own faith. So, my lord, we did not write with the confidence that we could persuade a resistant person, but with the faith that we would not deny the path to good peace to one who is willing.

If this is in your mind and heart, there is no struggle with the name Catholic. If our people attain this through God, there is no need to question, with divine authority preceding. If through man, when usurped, it must be exposed. If the name is good, it does not receive hatred. If bad, it lacks envy.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Therefore, Lord, we haven't written with the confidence to persuade someone who resists. Instead, we've written with faith that we shouldn't deny access to those seeking peace. If this aligns with your mind and heart, there will be no struggle over the Catholic name. For if our people achieve this through God, there's no need to question, given divine authority. If through man, whenever it’s usurped, it should be exposed. If the name is good, it won’t receive hatred; if bad, it lacks envy.

I hear that the Novatians are named after Novatus or Novatian. However, I don’t accuse the name, but the sect itself. Similarly, no one has accused Montanus or the Phrygians over their name. You might say, under the apostles, no one was called Catholic. So be it, let that be allowed. When heresies arose after the apostles, trying to tear and divide God's dove and queen into parts with various names, didn’t the apostolic people demand a name to distinguish the unity of the uncorrupted people so that the pure virgin of God wouldn’t be torn apart by the errors of some members? Wasn't it fitting to mark the principal head with its own name?

Suppose I entered a populous city today and found Marcionites, Apollinarians, Cataphrygians, Novatians, and others who called themselves Christians. How would I recognize the congregation of my people if it weren’t called Catholic? Come on, who has granted such names to the other peoples? Why do so many cities and nations have their own descriptions? The very one who questions the Catholic name wouldn’t know the reason for his own name if I asked where it was handed down to him. Certainly, it wasn’t borrowed from man, as it has endured for so many centuries.

This Catholic name doesn’t sound like Marcion, Apelles, or Montanus, nor does it take heretics as its authors. The Holy Spirit, whom God sent from heaven as a teacher and comforter to the apostles, has taught many of us; reason, as Paul says, and honesty, and, as he says, nature itself have taught many things. What? Do we have little authority from the apostolic men, little from the first priests, little from the most blessed martyr and teacher Cyprian?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Do we want to teach the teacher? Are we wiser than him, and are we driven by the spirit of the flesh against him, whom the noble blood and the crown of the most illustrious passion of the eternal God have produced as a witness?

What about all those priests from different regions, whom the same peace united with Cyprian throughout the entire world? What about all those aged bishops, all those martyrs, all those confessors?

Come on. If they were not suitable authors by claiming this name, will we be suitable by denying it? Will our authority be followed by the fathers, and will the antiquity of the saints yield to be corrected? Will the times, now decaying with vices, erase the canons of apostolic antiquity?

I hear Novatians being called after Novatus or Novatian: however, I do not accuse the sect by their name; nor did anyone object to the name of Montanus or the Phrygians. But you will say, under the apostles, no one was called Catholic.

Let it be so, allow that. When heresies arose after the apostles and tried to tear and divide the dove of God and the queen into parts under different names: didn't the apostolic flock ask for its own name to distinguish the unity of the uncorrupted people, so that the virgin of God would not be torn apart by the error of some through the members? Wasn't it fitting for the principal head to be marked with its own name?

Suppose I entered a populous city today and found Marcionites, Apollinarians, Cataphrygians, Novatians, and others of that kind, who called themselves Christians: by what name would I recognize the congregation of my people if it were not called Catholic?

Come on, who gave such names to the other peoples? Why does each city, each nation have its own description? The one who questions the Catholic name would not know the reason for his own name if I asked from where it was handed down to me. Certainly, it was not borrowed from a man, that which has not fallen through so many ages. The name Catholic does not sound like Marcion, nor Apelles, nor Montanus, nor does it take heretical authors.

The Holy Spirit has taught us many things, whom God sent from heaven to the apostles as a comforter and teacher; much reason, as Paul says, and honesty, and, as he says, nature itself. What then?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Do we give little authority to the apostolic men, the first priests, or the blessed martyr and teacher Cyprian? Do we want to teach the teacher? Are we wiser than he is? Are we driven by worldly desires against him, whom noble blood and the crown of a great passion have made a witness of the eternal God?

What about all the priests across different places, united in peace with Cyprian throughout the world? What about the elderly bishops, the martyrs, the confessors? Come on. If they were not suitable authorities by claiming this name, will we be suitable by denying it? Will our authority surpass that of the fathers? Will we correct the traditions of the saints? Will our current, vice-ridden times erase the canons of apostolic antiquity?

But do not be troubled, brother: Christian is my name, Catholic is my surname. The former calls me; the latter defines me. By this, I am approved; by that, I am identified. If the meaning of the word Catholic must finally be given and explained from Greek to Roman: Catholic means one, or as the more learned believe, obedience to all, namely to the commandments of God. Hence the Apostle: If you are obedient in all things (Second Corinthians 2:9). And again: For as by the disobedience of one many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one, many will be made righteous (Romans 5:19). Therefore, he who is Catholic is also obedient to the righteous. He who is obedient is also a Christian: thus, a Catholic is a Christian.

Therefore, our people are separated from heretics by the name Catholic. Additionally, if Catholic means one everywhere, as the superior ones think, David indicates the same saying: The queen stood in a golden vestment and adorned (Psalms 45:10), that is, one in all. And in the Song of Songs, the Groom says: My dove is one, my perfect one, she is the only one of her mother, she is the chosen one of her who bore her (Song of Solomon 6:8). And again: Virgins will be brought to the king after her (Psalms 45:15). And still: Young maidens without number (Song of Solomon 6:7). Therefore, in all things one, and one above all.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
But don't worry, brother: Christian is my name, and Catholic is my surname. The first identifies me; the second describes me. This is how I am known, and that is how I am signified.

If we need to explain the meaning of the word Catholic and translate it from Greek into Latin: Catholic means 'universal', or, as the more educated think, 'obedient to all God's commandments.' Hence the Apostle says, "If you are obedient in everything" Second Corinthians 2:9. And again: "For just as through the disobedience of one man many were made sinners, so also through the obedience of one man many will be made righteous" Romans 5:19.

Therefore, a Catholic is also obedient to righteousness. Whoever is obedient is also a Christian: thus, a Catholic is a Christian. This is why our people are distinguished from heretics by this name, Catholic: and if Catholic means 'one everywhere,' as the elders think, David also indicates this when he says, "The queen stood in gold from Ophir" Psalm 45:9, that is, one in all things.

In the Song of Songs, the Bridegroom says: "My dove, my perfect one, is unique, the only daughter of her mother, chosen by the one who bore her" Song of Solomon 6:9. And again: "They will be led to the king, the virgins, her companions who follow her" Psalm 45:14.

And also: "The maidens, without number" Song of Solomon 6:8. Therefore, she is one in all things and one above all. If you seek the reason for the name, it is clear.

As for repentance, may God grant that it is never necessary for the faithful; may no one fall into the pit of death after the help of the holy font: nor should priests be forced to offer late consolations or teach them, lest they open the way to sin while comforting the sinner with remedies. But we reveal this indulgence of our God to the wretched, not to the blessed, not before sin, but after sins are revealed: and we announce healing not to the healthy, but to the sick.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If spiritual evils have no power over the baptized, then neither does the deceit of that serpent which first led humanity astray and imposed so many titles of damnation on its descendants. If it has retreated from the world, if we have already begun to reign, if no sin sneaks into our eyes, hands, or minds, then let this gift of God be discarded. Let help be rejected, let no confession, no groans be heard; let proud justice scorn every remedy.

But if the Lord has provided this for His people, if He has granted rewards to those who stand and remedies to those who fall, then stop accusing divine mercy. Stop erasing so many titles of heavenly clemency with rigorous objections, or denying the Lord’s free gifts with unyielding harshness.

We do not grant these things from our own resources. Turn to me, says the Lord, along with fasting, weeping, and mourning; tear your hearts. Joel 2:12. And again: Let the wicked forsake his ways, and the unrighteous man his thoughts, and let him return to the Lord, and He will have mercy on him. Isaiah 55:7. Likewise, the Prophet cries out in this way: Because God is gracious, and merciful, patient, and who relents from sending calamity. Joel 2:13.

Does the serpent have such lasting venom, and Christ does not have a remedy? The devil kills in the world, and Christ cannot help here?

Certainly, let it be painful to sin, but let it not be painful to repent. Let it be shameful to be in danger, but not shameful to be delivered.

Who would take away a plank from a shipwrecked person to prevent their escape? Who would begrudge the healing of wounds?

Does not David say: I drench my bed with my tears every night; I flood my couch with weeping. Psalm 6:6. And again: I acknowledge my sin; I did not cover up my iniquity. Psalm 32:5. And further: I said, "I will confess my transgressions to the Lord," and you forgave the guilt of my sin.

Did not the prophet respond to David after his guilt of murder and adultery, for Bathsheba’s repentance: The Lord has taken away your sin. Second Samuel 12:13.

Did not confession free the Babylonian king after so many crimes of idolatry?

chunks.cleaned_english_translation: And what does the Lord say: "Does not one who falls get up, and the one who turns away come back?" (Jeremiah 8:4). What do those many examples of the Lord's arguments respond to? The woman who finds the lost coin and rejoices; the shepherd who brings back the wandering sheep; the father who warmly welcomes his returning son, after he squandered all his wealth and lived with prostitutes and sinners, and who scolds the jealous brother by showing reason? Saying, "This son of mine was dead and has come back to life; he was lost and is found" (Luke 15:32). What about the man injured on the road, ignored by the Levite and the priest? Doesn’t he get healed? Now I rejoice, says the Apostle, because you were made sorrowful to repentance (Second Corinthians 7:9). Didn't the prophet respond after David was guilty of murder and adultery, and repented for Bathsheba: "The Lord has taken away your sin" 2 Samuel 12:13?

Didn't repentance free the Babylonian king after so many acts of idolatry condemned him? And what does the Lord mean when He says: "Doesn't the one who falls rise again, and the one who turns away return" Jeremiah 8:4?

What do all those parables of the Lord mean? That the woman finds the lost coin and rejoices; that the shepherd brings back the wandering sheep; that the father lovingly meets the returning son after he squandered all his wealth with prostitutes and sinners, and reproves the envious brother? The father says, "This son of mine was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found" Luke 15:32.

What about the man who was wounded on the road, and passed by the Levite and the priest? Isn't he healed?

Consider what the Spirit says to the churches: He accuses the Ephesians of abandoned love; charges the Thyatirans with adultery; rebukes the Sardians for their incomplete works, the Pergamenes for teaching false doctrines; scorches the Laodiceans for their wealth; yet invites all to repentance through atonement.

What does the Apostle say to the Corinthians? "I fear that when I come, I may grieve over many who have sinned earlier and have not repented of the impurity, sexual immorality, and debauchery they have committed" 2 Corinthians 12:21.

And again to the Galatians? "If someone is caught in a sin, you who live by the Spirit should restore that person gently, but watch yourselves, or you also may be tempted" Galatians 6:1.

Does the master of a great house keep only silver and gold vessels? Doesn't he also keep vessels of clay and wood, some for special purposes and some for common use?

Now I rejoice, says the Apostle, not because you were made sorrowful, but because your sorrow led you to repentance 2 Corinthians 7:9. And again: "Godly sorrow brings repentance that leads to salvation and leaves no regret" 2 Corinthians 7:10.

But one could not repent. No one commands labor without reward: "The worker is worthy of his wages" Matthew 10:10; Luke 10:7.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Is this only allowed for the Apostles? Then is it also only allowed for them to baptize, give the Holy Spirit, and cleanse the sins of the nations? Because all of this was commanded to no one else but the Apostles. But if in one place, both the loosening of bonds and the power of the sacrament are given; either all of it is derived to us from the form and power of the Apostles, or none of it is released from the decrees. "I, Paul, laid the foundation, and another builds on it," First Corinthians 3:10. Therefore, we build on what the Apostles' teaching has founded. Moreover, bishops are also called Apostles, as Paul explains about Epaphroditus: "My brother and fellow worker, but your apostle" Philippians 2:25.

If the authority of baptism and chrism, and even greater gifts, have descended to the bishops; then the right to bind and to loose has also been given. Even if we claim it rashly because of our sins, God will still not deny it to those who hold the seat of the Apostles and saints; He even granted them the name of His Only Son.

I would write more, brother, if I were not pressed by the urgency of the returning messenger, and if I did not wish to save more detailed writings either for you in person or to confess the whole purpose. No one should despise a bishop because of human considerations. Let us remember that the Apostle Peter called our Lord a bishop: "But now you have returned to the Shepherd and Bishop of your souls" First Peter 2:25.

What will be denied to a bishop, in whom the name of God works? He will indeed give an account if he has done anything wrong, or judged corruptly and impiously. Nor is God prejudiced against rescinding the works of a wicked builder: meanwhile, if the administration is pious, it continues as an aid to God's works. Behold, the Apostle writes to the laypeople: "If you forgive anyone, I do too. And what I have forgiven, if there was anything to forgive, I have forgiven in the sight of Christ for your sake, so that Satan might not outwit us; for we are not unaware of his schemes" Second Corinthians 2:10-11.

If the Apostle says he has forgiven what the laypeople have forgiven, how will what a bishop has done be rejected?
